title: Bourbon Wieners Recipe
description: These bourbon weenies are made with bite-sized hot dog pieces simmered in a super-easy sauce flavored with bourbon whiskey for a fast appetizer.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Appetizers and Snacks Meat and Poultry Bourbon Wieners 4.4 (19) 15 Reviews 5 Photos These bourbon weenies make a great appetizer. They've been a family favorite for many years. Submitted by Aimee Stooksbury Hower Updated on February 6, 2023 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 5 5 5 Prep Time: 10 mins Cook Time: 10 mins Total Time: 20 mins Servings: 10 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 10 servings 1 (16 ounce) package hot dogs, cut into bite-size pieces ½ cup bourbon whiskey ½ cup ketchup ½ cup brown sugar Directions Place hot dogs, bourbon whiskey, ketchup, and brown sugar into a saucepan over medium heat. Heat, stirring often, until brown sugar is dissolved and sauce is bubbly, 10 to 15 minutes. Tips You can also make this recipe in a slow cooker. You can use uncut small smoky sausages instead of hot dogs. I Made It Print 32 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 231 Calories 13g Fat 16g Carbs 5g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 10 Calories 231 % Daily Value * Total Fat 13g 17% Saturated Fat 5g 26% Cholesterol 24mg 8% Sodium 648mg 28% Total Carbohydrate 16g 6% Total Sugars 15g Protein 5g 11% Vitamin C 2mg 2% Calcium 18mg 1% Iron 1mg 4% Potassium 131mg 3% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Bourbon Wieners 01 of 05 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 05 Photo by  tsltzr 12/25/2021 Tasty. I used 'Lil Smokies and after heating it up decided to place them under the broiler to crisp them a bit. Cooked down the sauce to more of a glaze this way. 03 of 05 Photo by  tsltzr 12/25/2021 Tasty. I used 'Lil Smokies and after heating it up decided to place them under the broiler to crisp them a bit. Cooked down the sauce to more of a glaze this way. 04 of 05 Photo by  lutzflcat 02/24/2013 Nothing really new here, this is a recipe buried in many people's recipe boxes long before the internet even existed. Good, as always.----UPDATE 4.24.14---Used this recipe’s standard sauce ingredients, but I substituted Johnsonville® Italian Hot Sausage links for the wieners. I did brown the slices on both sides in a non-stick skillet and then they went into the sauce. The first bite gives you a sweet saucy taste, then the spiciness kicks in with the sausage. Maybe an unlikely combination of ingredients, but these flavors partner well, and they all disappeared VERY quickly. Just another, totally different option. 1 You’ll Also Love Bacon Wrapped Pretzels 6 Ratings Bacon-Wrapped Tater Tots 20 Ratings Cofer's Hot Wings 1 Rating Easy Lemon-Pepper Chicken Wings 120 Ratings Delish Black Mission Figs! 6 Ratings Bacon-Wrapped Pickles 26 Ratings Lemon Pepper Wings 7 Ratings Memphis Wontons 2 Ratings Bourbon Little Smokies 12 Ratings Lemon Pepper Chicken Wings 64 Ratings Lubed-Up Hot Wings 5 Ratings English Muffin Pizza 14 Ratings Best Breakfast Sausage Balls Ever 36 Ratings Easy Appetizer Meatballs 7 Ratings Kentucky Beer Cheese 1 Rating Big Game Dip 19 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Aimee Stooksbury Hower
instructions: Place hot dogs, bourbon whiskey, ketchup, and brown sugar into a saucepan over medium heat. Heat, stirring often, until brown sugar is dissolved and sauce is bubbly, 10 to 15 minutes.
